sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 44045/05) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yuriy Ivanovich Moskalev (“the applicant”), on 27 October 2005.
2.  The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation at the European Court of Human Rights, and then by his successor in that office, Mr M. Galperin.
3.  The applicant alleged, in particular, that he had been subjected to covert surveillance in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
4.  On 20 March 2009 the application was communicated to the Government.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Omsk.
6.  The applicant was deputy head of the Omsk Regional Department for the Execution of Sentences.
7.  On 22 August 2002 the Novosibirsk Regional Court authorised for 180 days the interception and recording of the applicant’s telephone conversations, interception of postal communications and the collection of data from technical channels of communication. The surveillance authorisation read in its entirety as follows:
“Operational-search measures carried out with the aim of combatting corruption within State authorities have revealed indications of a systematic bribery scheme operated by certain prison officials in the Omsk region.
According to operative information, there are good reasons to suspect [the applicant], deputy head of the Omsk Regional Department for the Execution of Sentences, of arranging for, and systematically receiving, unlawful payments from confidants of the convicts serving their sentences in Omsk penal institutions in exchange for granting them various privileges (such as a prison leave, improved conditions of detention or transfer to another penal institution within the Omsk region, which was for some reason preferred by the convict in question).
Given that [the applicant’s] actions contain elements of criminal offences under Article 290 § 4 of the Criminal Code [bribe-taking], classified as a serious offence, and under Article 285 § 1 of the Criminal Code [abuse of power], it is necessary to perform a combination of operational-search measures (interception and recording of telephone conversations, monitoring of correspondence and collection of data from technical channels of communication) in order to collect evidence of his criminal activities, and to receive information about the bribegivers and the payment mechanisms used.”
8.  On 18 February 2003 the Novosibirsk Regional Court authorised “audio surveillance” of the applicant’s office for 180 days. The Government did not submit a copy of that decision.
9.  Charges of bribe-taking or abuse of power have never been brought against the applicant.
10.  In March 2003 the applicant was charged with disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code, for informing a convict’s relative that the convict was under covert surveillance.
11.  When studying the criminal case file, the applicant learnt for the first time that his telephone conversations had been recorded and his other communications monitored. He also learnt that a recording of his telephone conversation with Ms L., a sister of a convict detained in a penal institution under his supervision, formed the basis for the charge of disclosure of State secrets. During the conversation, which had taken place on 17 October 2002, the applicant had warned Ms L. that her relative was under covert surveillance and that there were listening devices hidden in his cell.
12.  At the trial the applicant pleaded not guilty. He claimed, in particular, that the recording of his telephone conversation with Ms L. was inadmissible as evidence as it had been obtained unlawfully.
13.  On 16 February 2005 the Omsk Regional Court found the applicant guilty of disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code. It relied on the recording of the applicant’s telephone conversation with Ms L., among other evidence. It found that the recording was admissible as evidence as it had been obtained in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law. In particular, the interception of the applicant’s telephone conversations had been authorised by a court on the grounds that he was suspected of the serious criminal offence of bribetaking. The applicant was sentenced to three years’ imprisonment, suspended for two years.
14.  In his appeal submissions the applicant complained, in particular, of a violation of his right to respect for his private life. He argued that the interception of his communications had been unlawful and unjustified, and that the recording of his conversation with Ms L. was inadmissible as evidence.
15.  On 21 June 2005 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the conviction on appeal. It noted that all the evidence had been collected in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law and was admissible.
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
16.  For a summary of the domestic provisions on interception of communications and use of the data thereby collected in criminal proceedings, see Zubkov and Others v. Russia (nos. 29431/05 and 2 others, §§ 40-57, 7 November 2017).
17.  For a summary of the domestic provisions on judicial review of operational-search measures, see Zubkov and Others (cited above, §§ 5876).

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Declares the complaint concerning the alleged breach of the applicant’s right to respect for his private life and correspondence admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
events.event_what: declares the complaint admissible

events.source_text: 2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: holds that there has been a violation of Article 8

events.source_text: 3. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event_what: holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant

events.source_text: On 20 March 2009 the application was communicated to the Government.
events.event_who: The Court (or implicitly the European Court of Human Rights)
events.event_what: communicated the application to the Russian Federation.

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that he had been subjected to covert surveillance in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
events.event_what: alleged that he was subjected to covert surveillance under Article 8.

events.source_text: On 16 February 2005 the Omsk Regional Court found the applicant guilty of disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code. It relied on the recording of the applicant’s telephone conversation with Ms L., among other evidence.
events.event_what: found the applicant guilty of disclosure of State secrets under Article 283 § 1.

events.source_text: The Court upheld the conviction on appeal. It noted that all the evidence had been collected in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law and was admissible.

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 44045/05) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a Russian national, Mr Yuriy Ivanovich Moskalev ("the applicant"), on 27 October 2005.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: The Russian Government ("the Government") were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation at the European Court of Human Rights, and then by his successor in that office, Mr M. Galperin.
events.event_what: were represented

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that he had been subjected to covert surveillance in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
events.event_what: had been subjected to covert surveillance

events.source_text: On 20 March 2009 the application was communicated to the Government.
events.event_what: was communicated

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Omsk.
events.event: Personal details of the applicant were provided
events.event_what: was born in 1960 and lives in Omsk

events.source_text: The applicant was deputy head of the Omsk Regional Department for the Execution of Sentences.
events.event_what: was deputy head of the Omsk Regional Department for the Execution of Sentences

events.source_text: On 22 August 2002 the Novosibirsk Regional Court authorised for 180 days the interception and recording of the applicant’s telephone conversations, interception of postal communications and the collection of data from technical channels of communication.
events.event_what: interception and recording of the applicant’s telephone conversations, interception of postal communications and the collection of data from technical channels of communication

events.source_text: On 18 February 2003 the Novosibirsk Regional Court authorised “audio surveillance” of the applicant’s office for 180 days. The Government did not submit a copy of that decision.
events.event_what: “audio surveillance” of the applicant’s office for 180 days

events.source_text: Charges of bribe-taking or abuse of power have never been brought against the applicant.
events.event_what: charges of bribe-taking or abuse of power

events.source_text: In March 2003 the applicant was charged with disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code, for informing a convict’s relative that the convict was under covert surveillance.
events.event_what: disclosure of State secrets

events.source_text: When studying the criminal case file, the applicant learnt for the first time that his telephone conversations had been recorded and his other communications monitored.
events.event_what: his telephone conversations had been recorded and his other communications monitored

events.source_text: At the trial the applicant pleaded not guilty. He claimed, in particular, that the recording of his telephone conversation with Ms L., a sister of a convict detained in a penal institution under his supervision, was inadmissible as evidence as it had been obtained unlawfully.
events.event_what: the recording of his telephone conversation with Ms L. was inadmissible as evidence

events.source_text: On 16 February 2005 the Omsk Regional Court found the applicant guilty of disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code. It relied on the recording of the applicant’s telephone conversation with Ms L., among other evidence.
events.event_what: disclosure of State secrets

events.source_text: In his appeal submissions the applicant complained, in particular, of a violation of his right to respect for his private life.
events.event_what: complained of a violation of his right to respect for his private life

events.source_text: On 21 June 2005 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the conviction on appeal.
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Russian Federation
events.event_what: upheld the conviction on appeal

events.source_text: The Court, unanimously, Declares the complaint concerning the alleged breach of the applicant’s right to respect for his private life and correspondence admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
events.event_what: the complaint concerning the alleged breach of the applicant’s right to respect for his private life and correspondence admissible

events.source_text: Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: Holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event_what: pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention

events.source_text: Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event_what: dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.

events.source_text: 1. The case originated in an application (no. 44045/05) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yuriy Ivanovich Moskalev (“the applicant”), on 27 October 2005.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: 2. The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation at the European Court of Human Rights, and then by his successor in that office, Mr M. Galperin.
events.event_what: represented

events.source_text: 3. The applicant alleged, in particular, that he had been subjected to covert surveillance in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
events.event_what: alleged

events.source_text: 4. On 20 March 2009 the application was communicated to the Government.
events.event_what: communicated an application

events.source_text: 7. On 22 August 2002 the Novosibirsk Regional Court authorised for 180 days the interception and recording of the applicant’s telephone conversations, interception of postal communications and the collection of data from technical channels of communication.
events.event_what: authorised the interception and recording of telephone conversations

events.source_text: 8. On 18 February 2003 the Novosibirsk Regional Court authorised “audio surveillance” of the applicant’s office for 180 days.
events.event_what: authorised audio surveillance

events.source_text: 9. Charges of bribe-taking or abuse of power have never been brought against the applicant.

10. In March 2003 the applicant was charged with disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code, for informing a convict’s relative that the convict was under covert surveillance.
events.event_what: charged with disclosure of State secrets

events.source_text: 11. When studying the criminal case file, the applicant learnt for the first time that his telephone conversations had been recorded and his other communications monitored.

12. At the trial the applicant pleaded not guilty. He claimed, in particular, that the recording of his telephone conversation with Ms L. was inadmissible as evidence as it had been obtained unlawfully.
events.event_what: pleaded not guilty

events.source_text: 13. On 16 February 2005 the Omsk Regional Court found the applicant guilty of disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 § 1 of the Criminal Code.
events.event_what: found the applicant guilty

events.source_text: 14. In his appeal submissions the applicant complained, in particular, of a violation of his right to respect for his private life.
15. On 21 June 2005 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the conviction on appeal.
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Russian Federation
events.event_what: upheld the conviction

events.source_text: 16. For a summary of the domestic provisions on interception of communications and use of the data thereby collected in criminal proceedings, see Zubkov and Others v. Russia (nos. 29431/05 and 2 others, §§ 40-57, 7 November 2017).
17. For a summary of the domestic provisions on judicial review of operational-search measures, see Zubkov and Others (cited above, §§ 5876).
FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event_what: declared the complaint admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible

events.source_text: 1. Declares the complaint concerning the alleged breach of the applicant’s right to respect for his private life and correspondence admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: held that there had been a violation of Article 8

events.source_text: 3. Holds

(a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event_what: ordered the respondent State to pay the applicant

events.source_text: (i) EUR 7,500 (seven thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
(ii) EUR 400 (four hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;
4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event_what: dismissed the remainder of the applicant’s claim

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 7 November 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

events.event_what: were represented

events.source_text: 3. The applicant alleged, in particular, that he had been subjected to covert surveillance in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.

events.event_what: authorised

events.source_text: 9. Charges of bribe-taking or abuse of power have never been brought against the applicant.
events.event_what: Charges

events.source_text: 10. In March 2003 the applicant was charged with disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 × 1 of the Criminal Code, for informing a convict's relative that the convict was under covert surveillance.
events.event_what: was charged

events.source_text: 11. When studying the criminal case file, the applicant learnt for the first time that his telephone conversations had been recorded and his other communications monitored.
events.event_what: learnt

events.source_text: 12. At the trial the applicant pleaded not guilty.
events.event_what: pleaded

events.source_text: 13. On 16 February 2005 the Omsk Regional Court found the applicant guilty of disclosure of State secrets, an offence under Article 283 × 1 of the Criminal Code.
events.event_what: found

events.event_what: Declares the complaint concerning the alleged breach of the applicant's right to respect for his private life and correspondence admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible; Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; Holds

events.source_text: 1. Declares the complaint concerning the alleged breach of the applicant's right to respect for his private life and correspondence admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
events.event_what: Declares

events.source_text: 2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: Holds

events.source_text: 3. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 × 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event_what: Holds

events.source_text: (i) € 7,500 (seven thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
events.event_what: is to pay the applicant

events.source_text: (ii) € 400 (four hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;
events.event_what: is to pay the applicant

events.source_text: (b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event_what: that from the expiry

events.source_text: 4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction.
events.event_what: Dismisses
